comments.body: A follow-up to #2154, did you see any indications this a problem? I didn't notice an improvement for the Java tests, but still good to make sure this part is correct.

I saw this go wrong on my machine while dealing with some permissions problems, but it's pretty likely that that doesn't have anything to do with the failures on travis. Still, good to take it out of the equation.

IIRC the testcases are running against the `./ftp/tmp/home` directory. So you can check in the test if the newly created directory exists.

https://github.com/akka/alpakka/blob/7dc6727bd2e02e562f0097f316017f2754211a0e/docker-compose.yml#L75

Yes, they are. 
I will update those tests

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +378,382 @@      val name = "sample_dir_" + Instant.now().getNano

      val source = mkdir(basePath, name)

      val res = source.runWith(Sink.head)

comments.body: You may drop these now. Yay.
You mean drop the whole "fail and report the exception in the result status if connection fails" test? It is currently ignored and I thought you might want to implement it another way.
Aha, I didn't notice it is ignored. I meant the `stopServer()` / `startServer()` comments. Leave it as it is.
Might be wise, I've seen timeouts as well. Are those actually to be expected? Do we know why those are so slow?

@raboof I don't know why they're so slow on Travis. Of course, it has to do with the fact that these tests need to start and stop FTP servers but we should do fine tuning on these instances in order to configure the servers properly for working on Travis builds.
Actually I've seen tests be quite slow on my local machine at times as well - but haven't taken the time to really dig into that yet.

  implicit val defaultPatience =
    PatienceConfig(timeout = Span(30, Seconds), interval = Span(600, Millis))

  "FtpBrowserSource" should {

comments.body: is it worth having a spec showing the "sad path?"  maybe an IOException when trying to write to a location without sufficient permissions?

thanks for reviewing, that's a fair point

maybe I could leave the anon user with writepermissions=false for the sad path + setup a different, write-enabled user for the happy path?
I can easily manage FtpServer permissions with the users.properties file, but still haven't worked out how to do it for Sshd/Jimfs (SFTP tests).
I haven't done yet either. It seems that you can control the permissions set with [chmod](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13150122/set-directory-permissions-chmod-with-jsch).

@juanjovazquez @eharik I tried several approaches, chmod being one of them. But ultimately, the underlying filesystem is Jimfs - which [does not support posix-like permissions](https://github.com/google/jimfs).

> For example, while setting and reading POSIX file permissions is possible with the "posix" view, those permissions will not actually affect the behavior of the file system.

I don't see an easy way of testing this without moving to - say - [Memoryfilesystem](https://github.com/marschall/memoryfilesystem).
The good news is that - somehow obviously - when trying it with my local filesystem, I get IOExceptions for permission errors.

WDYT?
I don't know what Akka members team will think, but seeing that it is so difficult to test this particular case, I would let it be. I'd stick to `jimfs` as it's been very rewarding up until now.
sounds good to keep it simple, and stick to `jimfs`
